questions.text:
A 25-year-old student has been experiencing yellowish discoloration of the palms for the past seven months, with no changes in sclera or mucous membranes and no history of chemical exposure. His lipid profile shows the below results: Laboratory investigations: 

 

 

Total cholesterol: 240 mg/dl (N = < 200 mg/dl) 

LDL cholesterol: 145 mg/dl (N = < 100 mg/dl) 

TG: 250 mg/dl (N = 60-150 mg/dl) 

HDL cholesterol: 45 mg/dl  (N = 40-75 mg/dl) 

Lipoprotein electrophoresis shows a broad beta band. 

 

Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia

 

Explanation:

 

Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia or broad beta disease, is caused by a defect in apolipoprotein E (apoE), which impairs the clearance of chylomicron remnants and IDL from the plasma.

 

Key features include:

  • Elevated total cholesterol and triglycerides (typically both increased)
  • Broad beta band on electrophoresis, due to accumulation of remnant lipoproteins
  • Palmar xanthomas — yellowish discoloration or deposits in the creases of the palms
  • Increased risk of premature atherosclerosis

 

This patient’s lipid pattern, broad beta band, and palmar discoloration (xanthomas) are classic for Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Familial Chylomicronemia (Type I) – Presents with very high triglycerides, creamy plasma, and eruptive xanthomas, usually without a broad beta band.
  • Option C. Abetalipoproteinemia – Features very low or absent apoB-containing lipoproteins, leading to low cholesterol and triglycerides, fat malabsorption, and acanthocytosis. Not seen here.
  • Option D. Type IIa Hyperlipoproteinemia (Familial Hypercholesterolemia) – Characterized by isolated elevated LDL, normal triglycerides, and tendon xanthomas. Not compatible with this lipid profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Type III Hyperlipoproteinemia by its unique clinical features:

  • Combined elevation of cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Broad beta band on electrophoresis
  • Palmar xanthomas

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p245, 246.

questions.text: Following is an image of a Zinc finger domain of a steroid receptor. Which of the following molecule is stabilising Zinc in this structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) cysteine residues

 

Option B:

 

In the structure of a zinc finger domain, zinc ions are typically coordinated by cysteine and/or histidine residues. These residues provide the necessary coordination complex to stabilize the zinc ion within the motif, contributing to the structural integrity required for the domain to perform its function in DNA binding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Finger-like projection - This option might be a conceptual misunderstanding. The term "zinc finger" refers to the shape of the protein domain, not a physical structure that stabilizes zinc. Thus, "finger-like projection" does not refer to a stabilizing molecule.

 

Option C: Leucine residues - Leucine residues are not typically involved in the coordination of zinc ions within zinc finger motifs. Zinc fingers usually require cysteine and/or histidine residues for metal ion coordination.

 

Option D: SH group of proteins - While the sulfhydryl (SH) group found in cysteine residues does interact with zinc, this option is less precise than specifying cysteine residues directly. The SH group contributes to the bond with zinc but does not describe the full residue or its context within the protein structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other DNA binding domains with their functions are shown in the following table.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 444

questions.text: A physician is consulting a patient about his elevated triglyceride levels. The patient is non-diabetic and has no history of alcohol overuse, factors known to influence triglyceride levels. The physician explains that a certain lipoprotein is primarily responsible for transporting triglycerides synthesized by the liver. Which lipoprotein does the liver use to transport these endogenous triglycerides?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VLDL

 

Option B:

 

Very Low-Density Lipoproteins (VLDL) are produced by the liver and are responsible for transporting endogenous triacylglycerols, which are synthesized by the liver, to adipose tissue and muscle. VLDL serves as the body's internal transport mechanism for lipids it has produced or extracted from the diet and processed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: These transport dietary, or exogenous, lipids from the intestines to other tissues in the body after a meal.

 

Option C: LDL: Primarily carries cholesterol to the body's cells rather than triacylglycerol.

 

Option D: HDL: Involved in reverse cholesterol transport, carrying cholesterol from the tissues back to the liver, and is not a primary carrier of triacylglycerol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p 226.

questions.text: A research team studying metabolic responses to nutrient deprivation measures enzymatic activities in subjects after a 24-hour fast. They aim to determine which enzyme associated with lipid metabolism shows decreased activity in this energy-conserving state. Which enzyme is the research team least likely to find elevated in the fasting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetyl CoA carboxylase

 

Option D:

 

  • Phosphorylation inactivates acetyl CoA carboxylase. Thus, AMP activated kinase (AMPK) phosphorylates acetyl CoA carboxylase and inactivates it
  • ATP inhibits AMPK, hence fatty acid synthesis is increased in a well-fed state.
  • Fatty acid synthesis decreases in fasting state
  • This enzyme is inhibited by palmitoyl CoA, the end product of fatty acid synthesis
  • Dephosphorylation of Acetyl CoA carboxylase is effected by protein phosphatase 1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: CPS–I: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is an enzyme in the urea cycle, which may have increased activity during fasting due to the breakdown of amino acids for gluconeogenesis, resulting in excess nitrogen that needs to be excreted as urea.

 

Option B: Hormone-sensitive lipase: This enzyme is responsible for breaking down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol, which is upregulated during fasting to provide energy.

 

Option C: Glycogen Phosphorylase: This enzyme breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which is then converted to glucose-6-phosphate for gluconeogenesis or energy production, and is thus upregulated during fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During fasting, the body downregulates enzymes involved in synthesizing storage compounds, such as acetyl CoA carboxylase, while upregulating enzymes that facilitate the mobilization of stored nutrients, like hormone-sensitive lipase and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 238

questions.text: In an experiment, a team of scientists incubates liver cells at 0°C and treats them with trypsin to digest surface receptors. The temperature is then increased to 37°C, and radioactive LDL is introduced to the culture. Subsequently, the labelled LDL is found inside the liver cells. What is the process responsible for the internalization of LDL called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Receptor-mediated endocytosis

 

Option D:

 

  • The LDL is taken up by peripheral tissues in the body by receptor-mediated endocytosis.
  • LDL receptors are located in specialized regions called clathrin coated pits. ​​Binding of LDL to the apo-B100 receptor by apo B100 → the receptor-LDL complex is internalized by endocytosis → endosome vesicle fuses with lysosomes → receptor is recycled and returns to the cell surface and LDL particle + apoproteins + cholesterol ester are hydrolyzed by lysosomal hydrolases → forms fatty acids and free cholesterol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Facilitated diffusion: Is the transport of low-permeability molecules with the aid of a carrier protein.

 

Option B: Pinocytosis: Uptake of small molecules in solution, is receptor –independent.

 

Option C: Phagocytosis: Process by which cells such as macrophages and neutrophils engulf large particles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Receptor-mediated endocytosis is the specific and efficient mechanism by which LDL is internalized by liver cells, involving the interaction of LDL with cell surface LDL receptors.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 257-258.

questions.text: In a neonatal intensive care unit at a research-focused hospital in India, a preterm newborn is admitted with signs of respiratory distress. The baby's mother had a complicated pregnancy, which led to early labor. The neonatologist considers the biochemical aspects that could be contributing to the baby's condition, specifically focusing on the surfactant composition in the baby’s lungs. A deficiency in one of the surfactant components is suspected. Which lipid component could be deficient in this preterm newborn, contributing to respiratory distress?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

Option B:

 

  • The major lipid of lung surfactant is produced by type II alveolar cells.
  • Surfactant reduces surface tension of the aqueous layer of lung and prevents collapse of lung alveoli.
  • Constituents of surfactants: Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) or dipalmitoyl lecithin (DPL), phosphatidyl glycerol, cholesterol and surfactant proteins A, B and C.
  • During fetal life, lung synthesizes sphingomyelin before 28th week of GA & when fetus matures, more lecithin is produced.
  • The lecithin-sphingomyelin (LS) ratio of amniotic fluid is an index of fetal maturity.
  • If the ratio is 2, it indicates full lung maturity.
  • Premature infants have a higher incidence of RDS because the immature lungs do not synthesize enough DPL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cardiolipin: or Di phosphatidylglycerol is a major lipid of mitochondrial membrane and extracted from myocardium. Decreased cardiolipin level results in mitochondrial dysfunction, heart failure, hypothyroidism, and myopathies.

 

Option C: Phosphatidyl ethanolamine: or Cephalin is found in bio membranes and possess amphipathic properties.

 

Option D: Phosphatidyl inositol: or PIP2 is present in bio membranes and plays important role in mediation of hormone action on bio membranes and also acts as a second messenger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is the major component of lung surfactant, which reduces surface tension in the alveoli, preventing collapse during exhalation. In preterm babies, surfactant production can be insufficient, leading to respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e :  p 216 , Lippincott 7/e : P 204

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluating a 6-month-old girl brought in by her mother. The baby has a history of repeated infections, fever, vomiting, and one seizure episode. There's a significant family history: an elder brother passed away at 3 years old from an undiagnosed condition. The baby appears lethargic and hypotonic, with bilateral nystagmus and a cherry red spot visible in both eyes. A blood examination reveals a decreased level of Hexosaminidase A enzyme, prompting the pediatrician to consider a genetic metabolic disorder. What is the most probable diagnosis for this baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tay-Sachs disease

 

Option C:

 

It is a sphingolipidoses or lipid storage disease, due to deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. 

 

C/F: Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula and progressive deterioration. Death by 3–4 years

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gaucher’s disease type 1: Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase, C/F: Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, no mental retardation, no cherry red spot 

 

Option B: Niemann Pick disease: Due to deficiency of Sphingomyelinase. C/F: Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness, hepatosplenomegaly with Cherry red spot in macula. Death by 2 years of age.

 

Option D: Sandhoff’s disease: Due to deficiency of Hexosaminidase A and B, c/f: Neurological deficit and MR with cherry red spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or insufficient activity of an enzyme called Hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside within lysosomes, causing progressive neurological damage.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 68,251.

choices.text: 2, 3 BPG is an intermediate of Gluconeogenesis
Binding of 2,3 BPG decreases the affinity of Hb to O2 and shifts the ODC to right
Binding of 2,3 BPG stabilises the R state
2, 3 BPG has increased interaction with HbF

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the interaction of hemoglobin with 2, 3-BPG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Binding of 2,3 BPG decreases the affinity of Hb to O2 and shifts the ODC to right Interaction of Hemoglobin with 2, 3 BPG

 

Option B:

 

  • 2, 3 BPG is an intermediate of Glycolysis synthesized with the help of 2, 3 BPG Shunt or Rapoport Luebering Cycle.
  • The Hemoglobin tetramer binds to one mol of 2,3 BPG in the central cavity formed by four subunits.
  • 2,3 BPG forms salt bridges with a terminal amino group of both β globin chain via, Valine, Lysine and Histidine.
  • Binding of 2,3 BPG decreases the affinity of Hb to Oxygen, by stabilizing the T state and shifts the ODC to right.
  • 2, 3 BPG has decreased interaction with HbF as histidine forms salt bridges with 2,3 BPG is not present in γ chain of HbF → Instead of Histidine it is Serine, so 2,3 BPG has less interaction with Fetal Hb → accounts for high affinity of HbF towards Oxygen.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 2, 3-BPG is an intermediate of gluconeogenesis: This statement is incorrect. 2, 3-BPG is formed from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate during glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C: Binding of 2,3-BPG stabilizes the R state: This is incorrect. 2, 3-BPG binds to and stabilizes the T (tense) state of Hb, not the R (relaxed) state, which has a higher affinity for oxygen.

 

Option D: 2, 3-BPG has increased interaction with HbF: This is incorrect. HbF has a lower affinity for 2, 3-BPG than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which contributes to its higher affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen transfer from the mother to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2, 3-BPG is a metabolite in the glycolytic pathway that binds to deoxyhemoglobin (Hb in the T or tense state) and stabilizes it, which decreases the oxygen affinity of Hb. This interaction is crucial for the release of O2 in tissues.

 

Binding of 2, 3-BPG to Hb thus facilitates the delivery of oxygen to tissues by promoting the release of oxygen from Hb, which is reflected as a rightward shift in the ODC.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 288.

questions.text: Sources of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis include all the following reactions, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase

 

Option C:

 

  • This enzyme converts oxaloacetate to malate & utilizes one NADH
  • The co-enzyme utilized for de novo synthesis of fatty acid is NADPH.
  • The sources of  NADPH for fatty acid synthesis are:
    • Pentose Phosphate Pathway (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase).
    • Malic enzyme (Converts Malate to Pyruvate)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is the first in the pentose phosphate pathway and is a major source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis by oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone.

 

Option B: 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase: Also part of the pentose phosphate pathway, this enzyme further contributes to NADPH production by oxidizing 6-phosphogluconate to ribulose-5-phosphate.

 

Option D: Malic enzyme: This enzyme catalyzes the decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, producing NADPH in the process, and serves as an additional source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase is not a source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis, unlike glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase, and the malic enzyme, which all contribute to NADPH production in the cytoplasm for biosynthetic processes such as fatty acid synthesis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 159.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with abetalipoproteinemia presents with an abnormal blood picture showing acanthocytes, alongside symptoms of hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia. Considering the pathophysiology of abetalipoproteinemia and the patient's symptoms, the abnormal red cell morphology and associated clinical manifestations are most likely due to the malabsorption of which essential nutrient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linoleic acid

 

Option D:

 

  • The genetic defect might result in malabsorption of two fatty acids given in the options, but only linoleic acid is strictly essential in the diet (EFA).
  • Linoleic acid and linolenic acid cannot be synthesized in the body and have to be provided only in the food, so they are essential fatty acids.
  • Arachidonic acid can be formed from linoleic acid, if the dietary supply of it is sufficient.

 

ABETALIPOPROTEINEMIA:

 

  • All apo-B containing lipoproteins are decreased due to defect in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein → TAG is not incorporated into VLDL and chylomicrons → absence of LDL and no absorption of Fat-soluble vitamins (causing mental and physical retardation).
  • Low Serum triglycerides, cholesterol and phospholipids.
  • Blindness due to degenerative changes in retina.
  • Erythrocytes have spiny projections (acanthocytes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ascorbic acid and (B) Folic acid: Absorption of water-soluble vitamins such as ascorbate and folate are not affected.

 

Option C: Arachidonic acid: Due to the genetic defect, malabsorption of arachidonic acid is also affected but it’s not an EFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abetalipoproteinemia is a disorder characterized by the malabsorption and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins and essential fatty acids, due to the inability to properly synthesize and secrete apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins.

 

Linoleic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid crucial for maintaining membrane integrity and function, including that of red blood cells. The deficiency in linoleic acid disrupts normal membrane structure, leading to the formation of acanthocytes.

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 182, 363.

choices.text: Ubiquitin is the most important chaperones

questions.text: A graduate student is preparing a presentation on protein folding and the role of molecular chaperones in maintaining cellular protein homeostasis. While researching, the student encounters various facts about chaperones but realizes one of the statements they've noted is incorrect. Which of the following statements about chaperones is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ubiquitin is the most important chaperones

 

Option C:

 

Ubiquitin is not a chaperone but a small regulatory protein that is involved in ubiquitination, a process that tags proteins for degradation by the proteasome. Chaperones, on the other hand, assist in the correct folding of proteins and the prevention of misfolded protein aggregation.

 

Note - Ubiquitin is the key molecule of protein degradation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Many chaperones do belong to the family of heat shock proteins (HSPs), which are upregulated in response to stress to protect cells by preventing protein aggregation and assisting in protein refolding.

 

Option B: Chaperones are ubiquitous and are found in organisms ranging from bacteria to humans, playing essential roles in protein folding and maintenance.

 

Option D: Chaperones are often referred to as stress proteins due to their upregulation in response to cellular stress and their role in protecting cells by stabilizing proteins and complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some Properties of Chaperone Proteins:

 

  • Present in a wide range of species from bacteria to humans
  • Many are heat shock proteins (Hsp) and are known as stress proteins.
  • Some are inducible by conditions which cause unfolding of newly synthesized proteins (e.g. elevated temperature and various chemicals).
  • They bind to predominantly hydrophobic regions of unfolded proteins thus preventing their aggregation.
  • They act as a quality control or editing mechanism for detecting misfolded or defective proteins.
  • Most chaperones have associated ATPase activity, with ATP or ADP being involved in the protein-chaperone interaction.
  • Found in various cellular compartments such as cytosol, mitochondria, and the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 609.

choices.text: A and R both are right, but R is not the Correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Niemann-Pick disease is a glycogen storage disease characterized by mental retardation, organomegaly, etc.


Reasoning (R): This is due to deficiency of enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

Choose the appropriate response.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A and R both are wrong

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a sphingolipidoses due to deficiency of the enzyme Sphingomyelinase
  • Lipid accumulating - Sphingomyelin
  • C/F: Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation and highly fatal in early life

 

Educational objective:

 

Niemann-Pick disease is not a glycogen storage disease; a type of lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin due to the deficiency of the enzyme sphingomyelinase. This leads to symptoms such as mental retardation and organomegaly. Hexosaminidase A deficiency, on the other hand, causes Tay-Sachs disease, not Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 251

questions.text: Which enzyme is known to contain the amino acid selenocysteine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B:

 

Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains the rare amino acid selenocysteine at its active site. This enzyme is crucial for reducing lipid hydroperoxides to their corresponding alcohols and for reducing free hydrogen peroxide to water.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glutathione reductase - This enzyme does not contain selenocysteine; it catalyzes the reduction of glutathione disulfide to the sulfhydryl form glutathione.

 

Option C: Thioredoxin peroxidase - Also known as peroxiredoxins, these do not typically contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D: Thioredoxin oxidase - This is not a commonly recognized enzyme with selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenocysteine (SeCys) is seen at the active site of the following enzymes:

 

  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • Glutathione peroxidase, which scavenges peroxides
  • Deiodinase that removes iodine from thyroxine to make triiodothyronine
  • Selenoprotein P, a glycoprotein seen in mammalian blood

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 215.

questions.text: Among the listed apolipoproteins, which one serves as an activator for Lecithin Cholesterol Acyltransferase (LCAT), an enzyme critical in the process of cholesterol esterification within high-density lipoprotein (HDL) particles?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apo A-I

 

Option D:

 

Apo A-I is the primary protein component of HDL particles and serves as an activator for LCAT. LCAT plays a crucial role in the esterification of free cholesterol on the surface of HDL particles, facilitating the maturation of HDL and its role in reverse cholesterol transport from peripheral tissues back to the liver for excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Apo B-100: This apolipoprotein is the primary protein component of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL), not associated with activating LCAT. Its primary role is in the structural integrity of these particles and in mediating their interaction with LDL receptors.

 

Option B: Apo B-48: Apo B-48 is found in chylomicrons and chylomicron remnants. It is essential for the assembly and secretion of these lipoproteins in the intestines but does not play a role in activating LCAT.

 

Option C: Apo A-II: Although Apo A-II is also a component of HDL, unlike Apo A-I, it is not known to activate LCAT. Its precise function is not as well understood as that of Apo A-I.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INHIBITOR OF ENZYMES: CI inhibits CETP, A-II, C-III inhibits LPL

 

ACTIVATOR OF ENZYMES:  A-I activates LCAT, C-I, II activates LPL

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed, pg -272.

questions.text: Which group among the following is responsible for buffering activity of proteins at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Imidazole group

 

Option D:

 

The imidazole group, which is part of the histidine amino acid side chain, has significant buffering capacity at physiological pH (around 7.4). This is because the pKa of the imidazole group is close to the physiological pH, allowing it to effectively donate or accept protons, thereby contributing to buffering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Sulfhydryl group - Present in cysteine, important for forming disulfide bonds, but not primarily known for buffering.

 

Option B: Indole group - Found in tryptophan, contributes to the protein's structural and functional aspects but lacks significant buffering capacity.

 

Option C: Phenyl group - Part of phenylalanine, contributes to hydrophobic interactions in proteins but does not have a buffering role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Only amino acid whose pKa value (6.1) is nearby physiological pH (7.4) is Histidine (Imidazole group), due to which it has buffering activity at physiological pH.

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 28.

choices.text: RFLP result from a single base change
Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine
HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes
‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS)

questions.text: A 3.5-year-old girl of Arabian descent presents to the clinic with severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR. The history provided by her parents includes fever, cough, pallor, weakness, and tachypnea. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Following diagnostic evaluations, sickle cell anemia (SCA) is diagnosed. Based on the information provided, which of the following statements about SCA is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS) — this is False.

 

Explanation:

 

In sickle cell anemia, the amino acid substitution involves replacing a polar residue Glutamate with a nonpolar residue (valine) at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

This substitution creates a hydrophobic “sticky patch” on the surface of the deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS) molecule. These hydrophobic patches interact abnormally with each other, leading to polymerization of HbS inside red cells, which causes the characteristic "sickling" shape of RBCs under hypoxic conditions.

So the false statement is that the “sticky patch” arises from a nonpolar → polar substitution — the reality is the opposite:
→ It’s a polar (glutamate) → nonpolar (valine) substitution.

 

 

Other Options:

  • Option A) RFLP result from a single base change:
    Correct — The sickle cell mutation involves a single nucleotide change (A → T at the 6th codon), which eliminates a restriction enzyme site. This difference can be detected using Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) analysis.
  • Option B) Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine:
    Correction: this statement is Correct.
  • Option C) HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes:
    Correct — Heterozygotes for the HbS gene (sickle cell trait) are relatively protected against Plasmodium falciparum malaria, explaining its evolutionary persistence in malaria-endemic regions.

     

Educational Objective:


In Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA), a single point mutation (A → T) at the 6th codon of the β-globin gene results in the substitution of Glutamate (polar) with valine (nonpolar). This creates a hydrophobic site ("sticky patch") on deoxygenated HbS, triggering polymerization, red cell sickling, hemolysis, and vaso-occlusive complications.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 417, 693.

questions.text: A medical researcher is exploring the immunological properties of different phospholipids. During a study designed to understand the role of phospholipids in autoimmune disorders, they isolate various phospholipids from cell membranes and assess their potential antigenic properties. Which of the following phospholipids possesses antigenic properties?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiolipin

 

Option B:

 

  • It is the major lipid of Inner Mitochondrial Membranes and is the only Phospholipid which possesses antigenicity.
  • It is recognized by antibodies raised against Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis.
  • Decreased levels of cardiolipin or alteration in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Plasmalogens are found in bio membranes in brain and muscle.

 

Option C: Phosphatidylinositol acts as a second messenger and plays a vital role in the mediation of hormone action on bio membranes.

 

Option D: Dipalmitoyl Lecithin / Di Palmitoyl Phosphatidyl Choline is the most abundant phospholipid of cell membrane, largest body store of choline and a major constituent of lung surfactant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiolipin is a phospholipid that has antigenic properties and can be involved in autoimmune responses, such as in the case of anti-phospholipid syndrome. It is commonly associated with syphilis, where it is the reactive agent in the Wassermann test, and with lupus, where it is targeted by anti-cardiolipin antibodies.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 108

questions.text: During a biochemistry tutorial, the discussion focuses on the various levels of protein structure and the types of bonds that stabilize each level. A key topic is the primary structure of proteins and the specific type of bond that links amino acids together in a polypeptide chain. Which type of bond is involved in the formation of the primary structure of a protein or polypeptide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

The primary structure of a protein or polypeptide is formed through peptide bonds, which are a specific type of covalent bond. An amide bond is another term for a peptide bond when referring to its chemical nature. Therefore, all the options accurately describe the bond involved in forming the primary structure of proteins.

 

Bonds responsible for protein structure

 

  • Two types of bonds stabilize protein structure:
     
  1. Covalent (Strong): - Peptide bonds (Amide bond), Disulfide bond (present in all types of protein structures)
  2. Non-covalent (weak): Hydrogen bond, hydrophobic interactions, electrostatic (or ionic or salt) bond, Vander Waals interactions (present in secondary, tertiary and quaternary protein structures)

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 34.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is least likely to include neurological symptoms in its classic presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gaucher’s disease

 

Option C:

 

It is a AR disorder.

Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase 

 

C/F:

 

Bony pain, pathological fracture

No MR (as beta-glucosylceramide is present in extra neutral tissue)

Hepatosplenomegaly present

Large amounts of glucosylceramide accumulated in macrophages causing: Eccentric nucleus and Cytoplasm’s Crumpled tissue paper appearance 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tay-Sachs disease: C/F: Neurological Symptoms, Mental retardation. Cherry red spot in the macula. Progressive deterioration No Hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option B: Niemann-Pick disease: C/F:  Severe CNS damage, mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, Cherry red spot in macula. 

 

Option D: GM1 gangliosidoses: C/F: Mental retardation, hepatomegaly, skeletal deformities. Angiokeratoma. Cherry red spot in the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher's disease, particularly type 1, which is the most common form, does not usually present with neurological symptoms. This type is known as non-neuronopathic and primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bones.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 260, 261.

choices.text: Point A represents the region where the amino acid is deprotonated.
Point B represents a region of minimal buffering.
Point C represents the region where the net charge on the amino acid is zero.
Point D represents the pKa of the amino acid carboxyl group.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the titration curve of a nonpolar amino acid as shown in the graph with points labeled A to D. Which of the following statements correctly interprets the designated regions on the curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point C represents the region where the net charge on the amino acid is zero.

 

Option C:

 

Point C on a titration curve usually indicates the isoelectric point (pI) of an amino acid, where it has no net electric charge. This point is particularly useful in predicting the behavior of the amino acid under various pH conditions. At the isoelectric point, an amino acid neither moves towards the anode nor the cathode during electrophoresis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Point A represents the region where the amino acid is deprotonated: The amino acid is fully protonated at Point A due to low pH and abundance of protons in the solvent.

 

Option B: Point B represents a region of minimal buffering & Option D Point D represents the pK of the amino acid carboxyl group: Point B represents a region of maximum buffering, as does Point D which is the pKa of amino group.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The amino acid could be lysine. C represents the isoelectric point, or pI, and as such is midway between pK1 and pK2 for a nonpolar amino acid.
  • Lysine is a basic amino acid and has an ionizable side chain.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: p 6-9.

questions.text: Which of the following color reactions is most likely used to confirm the presence of tyrosine in the protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Millon’s test

 

Option B:

 

Millon’s test is specifically designed to detect phenolic compounds, and it gives a positive result for tyrosine due to the presence of a phenol group in its side chain. When proteins containing tyrosine are treated with Millon’s reagent (which contains mercuric nitrate), a red color develops, indicating the presence of tyrosine. This test is unique among the options for its specificity to tyrosine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Aldehyde test - This test is not specifically associated with the detection of tyrosine in proteins.

 

Option C: Ninhydrin test - While ninhydrin reacts with amino acids to produce a color change (typically blue or purple), it is not specific to tyrosine; it is more broadly used to detect free amino acids, especially proline and other secondary amines.

 

Option D: Biuret test - The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of peptide bonds in proteins and is not specific for any particular amino acid, including tyrosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The phenol group of phenylalanine and tyrosine containing proteins, when heated with mercuric sulfate in sulphuric acid and sodium nitrite form red coloured mercury phenolate.

 

 

  • Done by Millon, 1812–1867.
  • Chloride interferes with this reaction

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 31.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In well-fed state, activity of acetyl CoA carboxylase activity is increased.


Reasoning (R): Citrate produced from acetyl CoA in well-fed state acts as an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right, and R is a Correct explanation of A

 

Option C:

 

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is an allosteric enzyme and is activated by citrate, which increases in concentration in a well-fed state and is also an indicator of a plentiful supply of acetyl-CoA.
  • Citrate favours conversion of the enzyme from an inactive dimer to an active polymeric form.

 

 

  • Inactivation is by phosphorylation of the enzyme and by long-chain acyl-CoA molecules such as palmitoyl CoA using feedback inhibition and inhibition of citrate transport from mitochondria to cytosol.                      

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl CoA carboxylase is an enzyme crucial in fatty acid synthesis. In a well-fed state, the abundance of acetyl CoA leads to the production of citrate, which can be transported out of the mitochondria into the cytosol.

 

Citrate serves as an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase, increasing its activity. This upregulation is consistent with the body's shift toward anabolic processes, like fatty acid synthesis, when there is a surplus of energy.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 237-238

questions.text: A molecular biologist is explaining to a group of students the unique process through which Apo B48 is produced in the body. This protein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons, which transport dietary lipids from the intestines to other parts of the body. By what mechanism is Apo B48 generated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

Option B:

 

  • Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons.
  • It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells.
  • Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein.
  • It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.  

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: RNA alternate splicing: This process involves the removal or inclusion of segments of the pre-mRNA transcript, leading to the production of different mRNA variants and, consequently, different proteins from the same gene. However, it is not the mechanism by which Apo B48 is produced.

 

Option C: DNA editing: DNA editing refers to direct changes to the DNA sequence itself, which is not applicable in the case of Apo B48 production.

 

Option D: RNA interference: RNA interference is a biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression or translation by neutralizing targeted mRNA molecules. It does not involve the production of Apo B48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apo B48 is generated through RNA editing, a post-transcriptional modification that alters the nucleotide sequence of the RNA, resulting in a shorter protein variant crucial for chylomicron formation in the intestines.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p226.

questions.text:
A biochemist is optimizing a protein assay by enhancing the protein's absorbance at 280 nm for better detection and quantification. The protein contains alanine, which does not contribute significantly to absorbance at this wavelength. The scientist is considering substituting alanine with another amino acid that naturally exhibits strong absorbance at 280 nm, which would increase the overall absorbance of the protein at this wavelength.

 

Replacing alanine with which amino acid will increase the protein's absorbance at 280 nm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

 

Option A:

 

Tryptophan has a strong absorbance at 280 nm due to its aromatic ring structure, which allows it to absorb ultraviolet light effectively. This property is utilized in protein assays, such as spectrophotometry, to estimate the concentration of proteins based on their tryptophan (and also tyrosine) content.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Arginine - While arginine is an important amino acid, it does not have significant absorbance at 280 nm.

 

Option C: Guanine - Guanine is a nucleic acid base, not an amino acid, and thus is not relevant in the context of protein absorbance.

 

Option D: Lysine - Like arginine, lysine does not significantly absorb at 280 nm and would not increase the protein's absorbance at this wavelength.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amino Acids which absorb 250–290 nm (Maximum at 280 nm) UV light are tryptophan, phenylalanine, and tyrosine.
  • Maximum absorption of UV light is by Tryptophan.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 21, 22.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents to the pediatric outpatient department with a history of recurrent gastrointestinal disturbances and lethargy over the past few weeks. Laboratory investigations reveal a microcytic, hypochromic anemia and elevated blood lead levels, suggestive of lead poisoning. Given this child's condition, which of the following enzymes would likely exhibit increased activity in the liver as a compensatory or pathophysiological response?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) δ -Aminolevulinic acid synthase

 

Option D:

 

  • This child is a case of acquired porphyria due to lead poisoning, as lead inhibits δ -aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and thereby heme synthesis.
  • So, the decrease in heme levels has 2 effects (i) derepresses δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase -1 (hepatic isozyme) → increase in its activity (ii) decreases the hemoglobin synthesis and results in anemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase: This enzyme is involved in the conjugation of bilirubin, not directly affected in lead poisoning.

 

Option B: Ferrochelatase: Lead poisoning actually inhibits ferrochelatase, decreasing its activity. Ferrochelatase catalyzes the insertion of iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme.

 

Option C: Heme oxygenase: This enzyme catalyzes the degradation of heme to biliverdin, free iron, and carbon monoxide. It is not specifically upregulated in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The effects of lead poisoning on the heme biosynthesis pathway, particularly the inhibition of specific enzymes like ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase, leading to a compensatory increase in δ-ALAS activity.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 326-327, 334.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents, who report that he has been experiencing unusual fatigue, frequent bruising, and episodes of bone pain over the last few months. The child has also been less active than usual, preferring to sit rather than play with his peers. On examination, the pediatrician notes pallor, and palpation reveals an enlarged liver and spleen. A complete blood count confirms anemia and thrombocytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and light microscopy of the sample shows cells with a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. Given these findings, which enzyme defect is most likely responsible for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Option A:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

 

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disorder due to Glucocerebrosidase defect → accumulation of glucocerebroside in lysosomes.
  • C/F: No cherry red spot in the macula, No mental deterioration (Type I), Haematological features: Pancytopenia, bleeding manifestation, Hepatosplenomegaly, Bone Pain and Pathological Fractures of long bones
  • X-ray Femur Erlenmeyer Flask Deformity
  • Bone Marrow Biopsy:  Gaucher cell with Wrinkled paper appearance/crumpled tissue paper appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of sphingomyelinase is associated with Niemann-Pick disease, which also presents with hepatosplenomegaly but typically includes neurological symptoms due to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in neurons, which is not indicated in this scenario.

 

Option C: Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency in Hexosaminidase A enzyme is related to Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily presents with progressive neurological symptoms due to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neuronal cells, not the features described in the presented case.

 

Option D: Beta-galactosidase: A deficiency in this enzyme leads to GM1 gangliosidosis, which includes severe neurological impairment and skeletal abnormalities in its presentation, distinct from the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of Gaucher's disease, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 260, 261

questions.text: A patient has a point mutation at a specific site which results in disruption of the α-helical structure in a segment of the resultant mutant protein. The most likely change that can occur in the primary structure of the mutant protein is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methionine to proline

 

Option C:

 

  • Proline, because of its secondary amino group, is incompatible with an α-helix.
  • Glutamate, aspartate, lysine, and arginine are charged amino acids and valine and alanine are non-polar amino acids. So, they are like for like replacements and are unlikely to cause any disruption of protein secondary structure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Glutamate to aspartate - Both are acidic amino acids with similar properties and would not typically disrupt an α-helix.

 

Option B: Lysine to arginine - Both are basic amino acids and are similarly structured, making it unlikely to disrupt the α-helix significantly.

 

Option D: Valine to alanine - Both are small, nonpolar amino acids that fit well within an α-helix without causing disruption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proline is known as a helix breaker because its cyclic structure creates a fixed kink that can disrupt the α-helix's regular geometry. A substitution of methionine to proline in a protein's primary structure is likely to disrupt an α-helical segment.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 38.

choices.text: The molecule carries no net charge
Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum
The buffering capacity of plasma proteins are mainly due to Histidine residue.
There is no mobility in an electric field

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the isoelectric pH (pI) of a molecule is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

 

Option B:

 

At its isoelectric pH, a molecule (such as an amino acid or protein) carries no net electrical charge, leading to minimal solubility in aqueous solutions due to reduced electrostatic interactions with water molecules. Contrary to increasing solubility and buffering capacity, both are actually at their minimum at the isoelectric point because the molecule has no net charge to donate or accept protons readily, thus reducing its ability to act as a buffer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The molecule carries no net charge - This is correct. At the isoelectric point, the number of positive charges equals the number of negative charges, resulting in no net charge.

 

Option C: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins is mainly due to Histidine residue - This statement is generally correct as histidine residues in proteins, such as those in plasma proteins, play a significant role in buffering due to the pKa of the histidine side chain being close to physiological pH.

 

Option D: There is no mobility in an electric field - This is correct. Since the molecule has no net charge at its isoelectric point, it will not move towards either electrode in an electric field.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pH at which the molecule carries no net charge is called an isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI).
  • At an isoelectric point, the amino acid will carry no net charge, all the groups are ionized but the charges will cancel each other. Hence, at isoelectric point, there is no mobility in an electrical field.
  • Solubility and buffering capacity will be minimum at isoelectric pH.
  • The buffering capacity of plasma proteins and hemoglobin is mainly due to histidine residue.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 20.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of skin fragility and blistering on sun-exposed areas. He also reports significant liver disease history and excessive alcohol consumption. Laboratory tests show elevated porphyrins in urine. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis related to porphyrin metabolism. Which of the following types of porphyria is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Porphyria cutanea tarda

 

Option B:

 

  • The disease is due to deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.
  • Precipitating factors -Hepatic injury caused by environmental (ethanol) and infectious (hepatitis B virus) agents and exposure to sunlight.
  • Porphyrin accumulates in circulation leads to cutaneous symptoms and gets excreted in urine, turning it red to brown.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acute intermittent porphyria: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen I synthase; C/F-Abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with increased urinary ALA and PBG.

 

Option C: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen III synthase; C/F- Photosensitivity with increased uroporphyrin I in urinary, faecal, and red cells.

 

Option D: Hereditary coproporphyria: Deficiency of Coproporphyrinogen oxidase; C/F-Photosensitivity, abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms with urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and faecal coproporphyrin III increased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common form of porphyria and is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 274.

choices.text: Increasing the synthesis and secretion of VLDL from liver resulting in high LDL levels in the blood
Inhibiting the binding of apoB to LDL receptor, thereby blocking the lipoprotein uptake and increasing the blood cholesterol levels
Decreasing the availability of LDL receptors on the cell surface, resulting in decreased LDL uptake and high blood cholesterol level
Preventing the cholesterol breakdown into bile acids in the liver

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with coronary artery disease (CAD) is being successfully treated with anti-atherogenic medication that targets PCSK9. Following treatment, his lipid profile normalizes, and his cardiac status improves. What is the primary function of PCSK9?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing the availability of LDL receptors on the cell surface, resulting in decreased LDL uptake and high blood cholesterol level

 

PCSK9 (Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9) normally binds to LDL receptors and promotes their degradation in lysosomes, which prevents the receptors from being recycled back to the cell surface. This natural function of PCSK9 decreases the number of LDL receptors available on cell surfaces, especially hepatocytes, resulting in reduced LDL clearance from the bloodstream and consequently higher blood cholesterol levels.

 

Anti-atherogenic medications that target PCSK9 (PCSK9 inhibitors) work by inhibiting this protein, thereby preventing LDL receptor degradation. This leads to:

  • Increased recycling of LDL receptors back to the cell surface
  • Greater availability of LDL receptors on hepatocytes
  • Enhanced clearance of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream
  • Reduced blood LDL cholesterol levels
  • Improved cardiovascular outcomes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Increasing the synthesis and secretion of VLDL - PCSK9 does not directly affect VLDL synthesis or secretion; its primary role is related to LDL receptor regulation.

 

Option B: Inhibiting the binding of apoB to the LDL receptor - PCSK9 does not interfere with apoB binding to LDL receptors; it affects the degradation of LDL receptors themselves.

 

Option D: Preventing the breakdown of cholesterol into bile acids - PCSK9's function is not related to cholesterol metabolism into bile acids; it specifically impacts the recycling and degradation of LDL receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that PCSK9 inhibitors work by preventing PCSK9-mediated degradation of LDL receptors, thereby increasing LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL cholesterol clearance, and lowering blood cholesterol levels in patients with coronary artery disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 271, 275, 278-279.

questions.text: In a discussion on protein synthesis, a molecular biology instructor outlines the role of aminoacyl tRNAs in the translation process. These molecules are essential for delivering the appropriate amino acids to the ribosome for incorporation into the growing polypeptide chain. However, one of the amino acids mentioned is not directly incorporated by this process. Which amino acid does not require an aminoacyl tRNA for its incorporation into a protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydroxyproline

 

Option A:

 

Hydroxyproline is not directly incorporated into proteins during translation by aminoacyl tRNAs. Instead, proline residues in a polypeptide chain are post-translationally modified to hydroxyproline. This modification is important in the stabilization of the collagen triple helix.

 

Note - Derived amino acids (Ex: Hydroxyproline) do not require aminoacyl tRNA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Methionine - Methionine is the first amino acid incorporated into most eukaryotic proteins and is brought to the ribosome by an aminoacyl tRNA.

 

Option C: Cysteine - Cysteine is incorporated into proteins during translation via its specific aminoacyl tRNA.

 

Option D: Lysine - Lysine is also incorporated into proteins by translation involving an aminoacyl tRNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 25.

questions.text: In a clinical study examining lipid metabolism disorders, researchers observe participants with markedly elevated plasma levels of chylomicrons and triacylglycerols. Which type of hyperlipoproteinemia is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I hyperlipoproteinemia

 

Option A:

 

  • Hyperlipoproteinemia I/Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (type I) is an autosomal recessive condition presents with fasting chylomicronemia and Hypertriacylglycerolemia due to deficiency of LPL or abnormal LPL or apo C-ll deficiency causing inactive LPL.
  • Slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL with low levels of LDL and HDL are noted.
  • C/F: Eruptive xanthoma; hepatomegaly; Pain abdomen, manifests in young age with less risk of coronary disease
  • A chylomicron band in fasting plasma is the characteristic finding of the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Familial Endogenous type - due to over production of TG by liver, elevated VLDL level → Cardiac manifestations. Associated with DM, obesity and impaired glucose tolerance.

 

Option C: Elevation of both CHL and TG with excessive production of apo-B → elevated LDL and VLDL.

 

Option D: Elevated CM and VLDL. Hypertriglyceridemia secondary to disorders like obesity, excessive alcohol intake, renal failure, pancreatitis, etc. are common. Other causes:  hepatic lipase defect, LCAT defect and Lp(a) excess and Wolman’s disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency, is characterized by markedly elevated plasma levels of chylomicrons due to a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase or its cofactor apolipoprotein C-II. This leads to an inability to hydrolyze the triglycerides carried by chylomicrons, resulting in high levels of both chylomicrons and triglycerides in the plasma.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: p245, 246.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with established coronary artery disease returns with new complaints of numbness in his hands and feet. On examination, below finding is observed. His lipid panel reveals HDL cholesterol levels are markedly low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tangier Disease

 

Option B:

 

  • Defects in ABCA1, an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) protein involved in transferring cellular cholesterol to HDL.
  • So, plasma HDL is low and alpha band is absent in electrophoresis.
  • Cholesterol esters are accumulated in tissues.
  • C/F: Large orange yellow tonsils, muscle atrophy, recurrent peripheral neuropathies and atherosclerosis. These are the hallmark features.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia: Here serum HDL is decreased → High risk for coronary artery diseases.

 

Option C: Familial alpha Lp-deficiency: Have ↓↓HDL and A-l, Normal- Cholesterol and TAG → Increased risk of CAD.

 

Option D: Hyper alpha lipoproteinemia: Increased HDL and is a rare condition apparently beneficial to health.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tangier disease by its classic presentation of orange-yellow tonsillar hypertrophy, neuropathy, and low HDL levels.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 236

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

questions.text:
Assertion (A): AIP (acute intermittent porphyria) has abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric features as common presentation.
 

Reasoning (R): The above symptoms are due to accumulation of ALA and PBG. ALA inhibits ATPase in the nervous system leads to conduction paralysis.

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of the Assertion and Reasoning provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A.                                                

 

Option D:

 

  • The defective enzyme in acute intermittent porphyria is hydroxymethylbilane synthase (uroporphyrinogen I synthase),
  • ALA and porphobilinogen accumulate in body tissues and fluids
  • C/F: Abdominal and neurological manifestations like sensory and motor disturbances, confusion, agitation and psychiatric problems.
  • No photosensitivity

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) is marked by a lack of porphobilinogen deaminase, causing delta-aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen buildup, leading to abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. This is due to ALA's neurotoxicity, which inhibits ATPase in neurons, resulting in neuronal dysfunction and paralysis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 328-329

choices.text: It is a basic structure of sphingophospholipids
It is a basic structure of  Glycosphingolipids
There are 2 types of glycolipids – cerebroside & ganglioside

questions.text: Based on the picture shown to you, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a basic structure of Glycosphingolipids

 

Options C:

 

The structure depicted is a general representation of glycosphingolipids, which are composed of sphingosine, a fatty acid, and one or more sugar residues. They play a critical role in cell-cell communication and are found in the myelin sheath of nerve cells. Defects in the metabolism of glycosphingolipids can lead to various neurological disorders.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect because sphingophospholipids have a phosphate group, which is not shown in the picture.


Option B: Incorrect because sphingomyelin is a type of sphingophospholipid and would include a phosphocholine or phosphoethanolamine group, not shown in the diagram.


Option D: Correct in the classification of glycolipids but not relevant to the structure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycosphingolipids (Glycolipids) do not contain phosphoric acid; instead contain carbohydrates and Ceramide (sphingosine + fatty acid  in amide linkage)
  • Contains 2 major subtypes : Glucocerebroside & Galactocerebroside
  • Sphingomyelins are the only sphingolipid that contain phosphate and have no sugar moiety

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 250, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 108

questions.text: Which organelle is primarily responsible for sorting proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golgi bodies

 

Option A:

 

Golgi bodies, also known as the Golgi apparatus, are responsible for the sorting, packaging, and modification of proteins that have been synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum. They play a key role in preparing proteins for their specific destinations, either within or outside the cell.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mitochondria: Electron transport chain, ATP generation, TCA cycle, beta oxidation of fatty acids, ketone body production, urea synthesis (part), heme synthesis (part), gluconeogenesis (part), pyrimidine synthesis (part).

 

Option C: Ribosomes: Biosynthesis of proteins.

 

Option D: Lysosomes: Degradation of proteins, carbohydrates, lipids and nucleotides

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functions of Golgi bodies:

 

  1. O-Glycosylation of proteins
  2. Protein sorting
  3. Processing of oligosaccharide chains of Glycoproteins

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 608.

questions.text: In an electrophoretic separation procedure, a technician observes the migration of lipoproteins from the cathode (-) to the anode (+) sidewhich of the following correctly orders the lipoproteins from cathode to anode?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CM > LDL > VLDL > HDL

 

Option A:

 

Plasma lipoproteins can be separated on the basis of their electrophoretic mobility:

Those with higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with less proteins have low mobility

 

Classifcation of Lipoproteins

 

Depending on the density (by ultracentrifugation) or on the electrophoretic mobility, the lipoproteins in plasma are classified into five major types 

  1. Chylomicrons: Contain apoprotein B-48.
  2. Very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) or pre-beta lipoproteins. Main apoprotein is B-100.
  3. Intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL) or broad-beta lipoproteins
  4. Low-density lipoproteins or beta lipoproteins. Major apoprotein in LDL is B-100.
  5. High-density lipoproteins or alpha lipoproteins. Major apoprotein in HDL is apo A.

 

Separation by Ultracentrifugation

The lipoproteins are characterized on the basis of their density. Fat is less dense than water; so fat floats on water. Lipoproteins with high lipid content will have a low density and so float on centrifugation. Those with high protein content will sediment easily and have a high density. 

 

Separation by Electrophoresis

As a general rule, those with higher protein content will move faster towards the anode and those with fewer proteins have minimum mobility.

 

Note : pattern of electrophoresis and ultracentrifugation are different as shown in the diagram.

 

Electrophoresis 

 

Standard order from Cathode (-) to Anode (+):

CM >LDL>VLDL>HDL 

 

Ultracentrifugation: sequence is 

CM > VLDL > LDL > HDL

 

 

Comparison of electrophoretic and ultracentrifugation patterns of lipoproteins.

(VLDL: very low-density lipoproteins; IDL: intermediate density lipoproteins; LDL: low-density lipoproteins; HDL: high-density lipoproteins; FFA: free fatty acid)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipoprotein electrophoresis separates particles based on their protein content and charge. Understanding the typical migration pattern helps diagnose dyslipidemias and distinguish between different lipoprotein abnormalities.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: 228.

questions.text: A general practitioner examines a 5-year-old boy who has been brought in due to concerns about his slow development and physical health. The child has noticeable abdominal swelling and a history of unsteady gait leading to frequent falls. Recently, he experienced a convulsive episode that prompted this visit. Clinical examination reveals significant hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory investigations, including a bone marrow biopsy, show lipid-laden foam histiocytes, and an enzyme assay indicates sphingomyelinase deficiency in the child's white blood cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niemann Pick disease

 

Option B:

 

  • Due to deficiency of Sphingomyelinase.
  • C/F: Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness, hepatosplenomegaly with Cherry red spot in macula.
  • Death by 2 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gaucher’s disease type 1: Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase, C/F: Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants but no cherry red spot

 

Option C: Tay-Sachs disease: Due to deficiency of enzyme Hexosaminidase Options A. C/F: Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula and progressive deterioration.

 

Option D: Sandhoff’s disease: Due to deficiency of Hexosaminidase Options A and Options  B, c/f: Neurological deficit and MR with cherry red spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niemann-Pick disease is associated with sphingomyelinase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in cells and tissues. The child's symptoms, including developmental delay, hepatosplenomegaly, difficulty walking, falls, seizures, and findings of lipid-laden foam histiocytes on bone marrow biopsy, are characteristic of this disorder.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 68,251.

questions.text: Three hours after a healthy middle-aged man eats a meal that includes carbohydrates, proteins, and fats, a blood sample is drawn to assess his lipid profile. Considering normal digestive physiology and the timing of the sample in relation to his meal, which component in his blood is likely to be elevated at this point?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chylomicrons

 

Option D:

 

  • After a well-balanced meal , the products of digestion such as glucose, amino acids, triacylglycerols are packaged as chylomicrons from the intestine and VLDL from the liver enter the bloodstream

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fatty acids: Fatty acids in the blood usually increase during fasting when fat stores are mobilized for energy, not postprandially.

 

Option B: Glucagon: Glucagon levels typically rise during fasting to promote glucose production and release by the liver, not after a meal when insulin is the predominant hormone.

 

Option C: Glycerol: Glycerol levels in the blood typically increase during triglyceride breakdown, which occurs during fasting or exercise, not postprandially.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The postprandial rise in chylomicron levels in response to a well-balanced meal, reflecting the normal physiological process of dietary fat transport.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 257-259.

questions.text: I-cell disease is characterized by a severe lysosomal storage disorder with symptoms manifesting early in life, including developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and coarse facial features. This condition results from a deficiency in a key enzyme necessary for the proper targeting of lysosomal enzymes. Without this enzyme, lysosomal proteins fail to be correctly trafficked to lysosomes. Which of the following recognition markers is not properly formed due to the deficiency of the phosphorylating enzyme in I-cell disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mannose 6-phosphate

 

Option B:

 

I-cell disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme that adds a phosphate group to mannose residues on lysosomal enzymes, producing the mannose 6-phosphate (M6P) recognition marker. M6P is essential for directing lysosomal enzymes to lysosomes. Without this marker, enzymes are secreted outside the cell instead of being targeted to the lysosome, leading to the accumulation of undigested substrates in lysosomes and the characteristic features of I-cell disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: GM2 ganglioside: This is a component of neuronal cell membranes and is accumulated in Tay-Sachs disease, not I-cell disease, due to a deficiency in Hexosaminidase A, an enzyme unrelated to the defect in I-cell disease.

 

Option C: Galactocerebroside: This is a major component of myelin sheath in the nervous system. Accumulation of galactocerebroside due to a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase enzyme is seen in Krabbe disease, not I-cell disease.

 

Option D: Globoside: Accumulation of globosides occurs in Fabry disease due to a deficiency in alpha-galactosidase A, which is not related to the enzyme deficiency observed in I-cell disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease is a condition in which lysosomes lack in enzymes but are seen in blood.
  • Mannose-6-phosphate is the marker enzyme to target the nascent enzymes to lysosomes.
  • In I CELL DISEASE, the carbohydrate units are not added to the enzyme → Mannose-6-phosphate deficient enzymes cannot reach their destination (protein targeting defect).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p586

questions.text: Is the statement "Calreticulin is considered a chaperone protein" correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True

 

Option A:

 

Calreticulin is a chaperone protein. It is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of cells and has several functions, including ensuring proper folding of newly synthesized proteins and maintaining calcium homeostasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molecular Chaperones are

 

  • HSP 70
  • HSP 90
  • HSP 40 [Cochaperone]
  • BiP [Immunoglobulin heavy chain binding protein]
  • Glucose Regulated Protein [GRP-94]
  • Calreticulin
  • Calnexin.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 608-610.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a familial history of increased cholesterol levels presents with an isolated elevation in LDL. His father and brother had similar lipid abnormalities. Given the isolated increase in LDL and family history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor mutation

 

Option C:

 

  • Lipoproteinemia are categorized by Frederickson's Classification
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) results in severe hypercholesterolemia associated with premature atherosclerosis.
  • The defect is in the gene for the LDL receptor or mutation in the ligand region of apo B100 → so, LDL is not cleared from the blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Familial type llI hyperlipoproteinemia: due to the abnormality in apoE , remnant clearance by the liver is defective resulting in increased levels of chylomicron and VLDL remnants. It can cause hypercholesterolemia, atherosclerosis, and xanthomas.

 

Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia: Defective loading of apo B with lipid → absence of formation of chylomicrons, VLDL or LDL, low blood acylglycerols with accumulation of it in the intestine and liver.

 

Option D: Familial LPL deficiency (type l): Due to deficiency of LPL or abnormal LPL or apo C-ll deficiency →  Hypertriacylglycerolemia with slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, low levels of LDL and HDL.

 

Educational objective:

 

LDL receptor gene mutation is characterized by isolated elevated LDL cholesterol levels and a family history of hypercholesterolemia and early cardiovascular disease.
 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 275,276.

questions.text: Based on the clinical presentation (as shown in image), which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial Hypercholesterolemia

 

Option B:

 

  • The deposition of lipids in subcutaneous tissue leads to xanthomas.
  • Xanthelasma are lipid deposits under the periorbital skin and contain mainly cholesterol.
  • Tendinous xanthoma are found over the tendons.
  • Deposits of lipids in cornea lead to corneal arcus; indicating hypercholesterolemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Familial Chylomicronemia: C/F- Hepatomegaly, eruptive xanthoma and abdominal pain.

 

Option C: Abetalipoproteinemia: Low levels of serum triglycerides, cholesterol and phospholipids. C/F- Blindness due to degenerative changes in retina and spiny projections in erythrocytes (acanthocytes).

 

Option D: Broad Beta Disease: Palmar xanthoma and increased risk for vascular disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

Familial Hypercholesterolemia is characterized by high LDL cholesterol levels and the presence of xanthomas, which are deposits of cholesterol in the skin and tendons, due to a genetic defect in LDL receptors.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9 /ed: P245, 246.

questions.text: Which of the following can be homologous substitution for isoleucine in a protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valine

 

Option C:

 

Valine is a homologous substitution for isoleucine because they are both branched-chain, nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acids of similar size. This substitution is likely to have the least impact on the protein's structure and function compared to the other options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Methionine - Although methionine is also nonpolar and relatively hydrophobic, it has a different side chain that includes a sulfur atom, which can affect the protein differently than valine or isoleucine.

 

Option B: Aspartic acid - This amino acid is polar and carries a negative charge at physiological pH, making it a non-homologous substitution for the nonpolar isoleucine.

 

Option D: Arginine - Arginine is a positively charged amino acid at physiological pH and is much larger, making it a non-homologous substitution for isoleucine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conservative (Homologous) Substitution:

 

  • One amino acid replaced by another amino acid of similar characteristics
  • Examples of homologous substitution is shown in the diagram given below.B

 

 

Nonconservative (Nonhomologous) Substitution:

 

  • One amino acid replaced by another amino acid of different characteristics

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 390.

questions.text: A researcher is utilizing different analytical techniques to study protein structures. Each method has a specific utility in the determination of primary, secondary, tertiary, or quaternary structures of proteins. Among the listed techniques, which one does NOT directly determine the structure of proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High performance liquid chromatography

 

Option A:

 

High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is a technique primarily used for separating and identifying components in a mixture, analyzing compound purity, or identifying concentration. It does not directly provide information on the structure of proteins at the level of detail that the other mentioned techniques do.

 

Note - The proteins are extracted and purified by various chromatography techniques such as ion exchange, adsorption, partition, size exclusion, affinity, HPLC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mass spectrometry can determine the primary structure (sequence of amino acids) of proteins and post-translational modifications.

 

Option C: X-ray crystallography is used to determine the three-dimensional structure of a protein at atomic resolution.

 

Option D: NMR spectrometry can provide detailed information about the structure and dynamics of proteins, particularly in solution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods for Separating and Purifying Biomolecules

 

  • Salt fractionation (e.g., precipitation of proteins with ammonium sulfate)
  • Chromatography: Paper, ion exchange, affinity, thin-layer, gas-liquid, high-pressure liquid, gel filtration
  • Electrophoresis: Paper, high-voltage, agarose, cellulose acetate, starch gel, polyacrylamide gel, SDS-polyacrylamide gel
  • Ultracentrifugation

 

Methods for Determining Biomolecular Structures

 

  • Elemental analysis
  • UV, visible, infrared, and NMR spectroscopy
  • Use of acid or alkaline hydrolysis to degrade the biomolecule understudy into its basic constituents
  • Use of a battery of enzymes of known specificity to degrade the biomolecule under study (e.g., proteases, nucleases, glycosidases)
  • Mass spectrometry
  • Specific sequencing methods (e.g., for proteins and nucleic acids)
  • X-ray crystallography

 

Ref: Harper 29/e: p 2, Vasudevan 9/e: p 45.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a notably disfigured face, pronounced photosensitivity, stained teeth, and laboratory tests revealing elevated levels of Coproporphyrin-I. Based on these clinical findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase                               

 

Option B:

 

  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria has AR inheritance
  • The defective enzyme - uroporphyrinogen III synthase leads to increase in levels of porphyrin I
  • Their excretion in urine makes the urine dark red in colour (port wine appearance)
  • Reactive oxygen species are the cause for attacks of dermatitis and scarring which leads to severe disfigurement referred to as ‘monkey face’. Also photosensitivity is reported.
  • When UV light is reflected onto teeth a red fluorescence is seen; this is called erythrodontia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Uroporphyrinogen Synthase - A deficiency in this enzyme would not lead to the specific accumulation of Coproporphyrin-I, nor would it directly result in the clinical syndrome described.

 

Option C: Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase - Deficiency in this enzyme leads to Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (PCT), the most common type of porphyria, which presents with skin fragility and blistering on sun-exposed areas, but not the severe disfigurement or erythrodontia seen in this case.

 

Option D: Coproporphyrinogen Oxidase - Deficiency of this enzyme results in Hereditary Coproporphyria, which can cause photosensitivity and neurological symptoms but does not typically present with the severe facial disfigurement or stained teeth as described in the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria (CEP), a rare disorder caused by a deficiency in Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase. The accumulation of specific porphyrins leads to symptoms including photosensitivity, facial disfigurement, and stained teeth, emphasizing the critical role of the heme biosynthesis pathway in maintaining normal physiological functions and the diverse clinical manifestations that can arise from its disruption.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 327-329

questions.text: Which amino acid can be converted into an intermediate that plays a role in both the citric acid cycle and the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspartate

 

Option D:

 

  • Aspartate is a glucogenic amino acid, which carries NH4 + into the urea cycle.
  • Aspartate aminotransferase catalyzes the direct transamination of aspartate to oxaloacetate
  • Oxaloacetate may either be utilized in the citric acid cycle or undergo gluconeogenesis.
  • Argininosuccinate synthetase catalyzes the condensation of citrulline and aspartate to form argininosuccinate.
  • In this manner, one of the two nitrogens of urea is introduced into the urea cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Tyrosine - Tyrosine is primarily used for protein synthesis and the production of hormones and neurotransmitters.

 

Option B: Lysine - Lysine is an essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis but is not a direct precursor to citric acid or urea cycle intermediates.

 

Option C: Leucine - Leucine is a branched-chain amino acid used in protein synthesis and can be oxidized for energy but does not directly feed into the citric acid cycle or urea cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspartate can be converted to oxaloacetate, which is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle. Furthermore, aspartate is involved in the urea cycle, where it donates an amino group for the synthesis of arginine, which is then cleaved to form urea and ornithine. This connection highlights aspartate's role in both energy production and nitrogen disposal.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 203, 247.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man who consumes a fat-free, high-carbohydrate diet finds that he continues to gain weight. Considering the dietary influence on lipoprotein metabolism, which apoprotein is most likely to be elevated in his blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) VLDL

 

Option D:

 

  • Excess Carbohydrates in the body are converted to Acetyl CoA. These are then converted to Fatty acid, which gets esterified to form Endogenous TGs.
  • VLDL is the carrier of endogenous TGs. So, blood VLDL level is raised.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: Carry TAG from gut to muscle and adipose tissue

 

Option B: HDL: Carry cholesterol from peripheral tissues to liver

 

Option C: LDL: Carry cholesterol from liver to peripheral tissues

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fat-free, high-carbohydrate diet can lead to increased synthesis of VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) in the liver. VLDL is responsible for transporting endogenously synthesized triglycerides, which the body produces from excess carbohydrates, to adipose tissue for storage. This could contribute to ongoing obesity despite the absence of dietary fat.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 255-257.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease (CAD), currently undergoing treatment, is advised to implement lifestyle modifications and monitor his lipid profile quarterly. Among the lipoproteins evaluated, which one is characterized by the lowest lipid-to-protein ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HDL

 

Option C:

 

High-density lipoprotein (HDL) is known for having the highest protein content relative to its lipid content among the various lipoproteins, resulting in the lowest lipid-to-protein ratio. This high protein content contributes to HDL's denser nature compared to other lipoproteins and its role in reverse cholesterol transport, where it facilitates the removal of excess cholesterol from cells and atheromatous plaques in the arteries, transporting it back to the liver for excretion or recycling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: These are the largest lipoproteins with the highest lipid content, primarily triglycerides, thus having a high lipid-to-protein ratio.

 

Option B: VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein): VLDL particles are rich in triglycerides and have a higher lipid-to-protein ratio compared to HDL but lower than chylomicrons.

 

Option D: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein): LDL carries mostly cholesterol and has a lower lipid-to-protein ratio than VLDL and chylomicrons but higher than HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Among different HDL particles, percentage of lipids seen will be:  

 

HDL1 : 65%

 

HDL2  : 67%

 

HDL3  : 43%

 

Preβ-HDL : 30

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 478-479, 484.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes routine health screening, including a lipid profile, while fasting. Her results show a total cholesterol of 300 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol of 25 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 150 mg/dL. Utilizing the Friedewald equation to assess her cardiovascular risk, what is the LDL cholesterol level in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 245 mg/dl

 

Option A:

 

  • The total blood cholesterol in the fasting state is equal to the sum of the cholesterol in LDL + cholesterol in HDL + cholesterol in VLDLs.
  • This last term is calculated by dividing the triacylglycerol value by 5 because cholesterol accounts for about 1/5 of the volume of VLDL in fasted blood.
  • 300 = LDL cholesterol + 25+150/5
  • LDL cholesterol = 300-55= 245 mg/dl.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Friedewald equation, used to estimate the level of LDL cholesterol, is LDL = Total Cholesterol - HDL - (Triglycerides / 5).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9/e: p241, 242, Lippincott 7/e: p 244
